channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Bits Blog: Q. and A. on Heartbleed, a Flaw Missed by the Masses
item.description: The chief technology officer for Elastica, a cloud security firm, helped explain the security flaw and open-source software, and offered suggestions for how consumers can protect themselves.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: Zulfikar Ramzan, the chief technology officer for Elastica, diagrammed how the Heartbleed bug worked and how hackers may try to exploit it.

item.title: Bits Blog: With Declines Slowing, PC Sales Still Struggle
item.description: Reports from IDC and Gartner, two technology market research firms, showed no sign of a rebound for the PC, which has lost sales to tablets, especially among consumers.
item.dc:creator: By NICK WINGFIELD
item.media:description: Sony laptops on sale at a store in Tokyo in February. Microsoft's decision to end support for the Windows XP operating system spurred more customers to replace their aging PCs, especially in Japan, Gartner and IDC said.

item.title: Gadgetwise: The Many Alternative Computing Worlds of Linux
item.description: An alternative to Windows or OS X, the open-source operating system comes in a number of varieties, ranging from the familiar to the technical.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS J. FITZGERALD

item.title: Fashion in the Age of Instagram
item.description: The photo-sharing app has changed the way fashion is made, seen and shared.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW SCHNEIER
item.media:description: To produce a video of its fall 2014 show relying solely on images captured on the iPhone 5, Edun borrowed 20 smartphones. Hardly an eyebrow was raised.

item.title: Senate Committee Begins Its Review of Comcast Deal
item.description: The judiciary panel expressed concern over higher costs for consumers if a merger with Time Warner Cable were approved, but a Comcast executive downplayed the likelihood.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WYATT

item.title: App Smart: Review: Eerie and Interesting Apps for Games and Amusement
item.description: Apps that offer little in the way of information, advice or solutions, but much in the way of oddity and fascination.
item.dc:creator: By KIT EATON

item.title: DealBook: Go Daddy Said to Pick Morgan Stanley and JPMorgan for I.P.O.
item.description: The Internet registrar has hired the two banks to coordinate its initial public offering, though it isn’t clear yet how much money the company plans to raise in an I.P.O.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL J. DE LA MERCED
item.media:description: A recent GoDaddy.com ad featuring the Nascar driver Danica Patrick.

item.title: DealBook: Question-and-Answer Site Quora Raises $80 Million
item.description: Quora, a site that specializes in posting questions and answers from users, has raised $80 million from Tiger Global Management and four existing Quora investors.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GELLES
item.media:description: From left, Marc Bodnick, who leads Quora’s business and community teams, with Adam D'Angelo and Charlie Cheever, the company's founders.

item.title: Bits Blog: Hillary Clinton’s High-Tech Marketing Message
item.description: The former Secretary of State and possible 2016 presidential candidate gave a speech to a high-tech marketing crowd that showed how brand and message work in politics as in commerce.
item.dc:creator: By QUENTIN HARDY
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton on Tuesday. Social media “is not a substitute for real-life action,” she said.

item.title: Bits Blog: Twitter Gives a New Look to User Profiles
item.description: The social network, which is struggling with slowing growth, will automatically highlight a user’s most popular tweets and allow customers to customize their profiles more.
item.dc:creator: By VINDU GOEL
item.media:description: A screen shot of Michelle Obama's profile page with Twitter's redesign.

item.title: DealBook: Box Chief Invests in Supply Chain Software Company
item.description: With ambitions of changing supply chain management, a start-up called Elementum has raised $5 million from technology entrepreneurs.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM ALDEN
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aaron Levie, the chief executive of Box.

item.title: Bits Blog: Readers Respond: How Should Apple Spend Its Billions?
item.description: Among the suggestions for what Apple should do with the $159 billion in cash it has on hand were building a television, paying more taxes and even curing cancer.
item.dc:creator: By NICK BILTON
item.media:description: Apple is under pressure to return its cash holdings to investors, but readers say the company should pay taxes or invest in the future.

item.title: Bits Blog: Experts Find a Door Ajar in an Internet Security Method Thought Safe
item.description: The software behind the tiny padlock next to web addresses that promised to protect sensitive data is broken, a team of security researchers has discovered.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH

item.title: Bits Blog: Heartbleed Flaw Emphasizes the Need to Change Passwords — in a Bit
item.description: Immediately changing passwords after a security breach could feed a new password into a website that has not fixed the flaw, a security consultant said.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE LOHR

item.title: Bits Test Run: Crashing DJI’s New Drone Into Water and Land
item.description: While flying a drone is really difficult, when you finally get the hang of it you can take some gorgeous photos and videos.
item.dc:creator: By NICK BILTON
item.media:description: The Phantom 2 Vision Plus has a new built-in camera that eliminates wobble in videos and can travel greater distances.

item.title: European Court Rejects Data Retention Rules, Citing Privacy
item.description: The ruling strikes down a law, enacted after 2006 terrorist attacks in London and Madrid, that required telecommunications companies to keep information about calls and emails.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER

item.title: Target to Stock More Environmentally Friendly Products
item.description: According to the Organic Trade Association, the industry grew to $31.5 billion in sales in the United States in 2012 from $8.4 billion a decade earlier.
item.dc:creator: By ELIZABETH A. HARRIS

item.title: Bits Blog: Comcast Gives a Nod to a Future Apple Set-Top Box
item.description: In papers relating to its proposed merger with Time Warner Cable, the company gives a nod to a future Apple set-top box, even though Apple hasn’t introduced one yet.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: In a document on Comcast's corporate website, David L. Cohen, an executive vice president at the company, alluded to it seeing competition from the likes of Apple and Google, as well as more established TV providers like AT&T.

item.title: Cuba Social Media Project Was No Plot, Agency Says
item.description: The head of the United States aid agency told Congress that the program was not meant to destabilize the Cuban government, only to promote open communication.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON

item.title: Video Game Review: Kinect Sports Rivals Includes New Technology
item.description: Kinect Sports Rivals uses an upgraded sensor, bundled with Microsoft’s Xbox One console, to try to improve motion gaming.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN TOTILO
item.media:description: The game uses the upgraded Kinect sensor for motion-controlled virtual sports, including wall climbing and wake racing.

item.title: Bits Blog: Email From Steve Jobs Hints at How Apple Ticks
item.description: A 2010 memo written by Steven P. Jobs, which Samsung lawyers obtained as evidence to present to jurors during a patent trial, offered a peek into how the company operates.
item.dc:creator: By BRIAN X. CHEN
item.media:description: Steven P. Jobs speaking at an Apple event on Oct 20, 2010. A few days later he sent a memo that revealed tidbits about how the famously secretive company ticks.

item.title: Machine Learning: Samsung Edges HTC in New Android Phones
item.description: The Samsung Galaxy S5’s features, including a slightly better camera, make it the more logical choice over the elegantly simple HTC One (M8).
item.dc:creator: By MOLLY WOOD
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times
item.media:description: The Samsung Galaxy S5, left, and the HTC One M8 arrive in stores by Friday.

item.title: Proposed Merger Would Enhance Competition, Say Comcast and Time Warner Cable
item.description: The companies filed documents in support of the plan, which has faced opposition and will be the subject of a Senate hearing this week.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WYATT

item.title: DealBook Column: Tech Firms May Find No-Poaching Pacts Costly
item.description: Employees of technology companies have filed a class-action lawsuit that contends that illegal hiring practices among their companies has cost them billions in lost wages.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN
item.media:description: A class-action suit accuses Steven P. Jobs and Eric Schmidt of colluding to prevent their employees from being hired by rivals.

item.title: Bits Blog: The Big Data Challenge to Legacy Data Management Companies
item.description: Big-data software is a formidable threat to the economics of incumbents. A look at Teradata, a data warehouse software company, shows the challenge and how an incumbent is responding.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE LOHR
item.media:description: Mainframe computer sales — once the centerpiece of I.B.M. — now account for an estimated 3 percent of the company's revenue.
